About millennials and GenZ

I think one of India‚Äôs most misunderstood generations as far as marketers are concerned. I am one and I‚Äôve sat in boardrooms where I‚Äôve heard a variety of sweeping generalizations which I haven‚Äôt ever agreed with! So, I jumped at this opportunity to give my (or rather our) side of the story. Roughly 60% of this country is below 30. You can‚Äôt put a finger on reading this new breed of Indian. In terms of mindset, there is no right or wrong. You could be child-married, lesbian or someone who doesn‚Äôt believe in marriage. You could be politically charged, indifferent or even anti politics. Never has there been a group of people in this country so diametrically diverse, open to different ideas and closed to ‚Äòrules‚Äô.This is also by far the most wasteful generation India has seen. I remember sitting in a meeting with a major alcohol manufacturer, gloating about a spike in vodka consumption in middle India, post-2008. The curve was scary and suddenly vertical; the sort that marketers love. But it tells you something about the mindset of millennials. Consumption of alcohol is one story. Another is revealed when you walk around key landmarks and can smell all sorts of substances in the air. Weed being circulated as early as grade 11 is not unheard of. Not only Punjab, in my reading every major Indian city is Udta. Here‚Äôs a generation that wants to do a lot and forget. We‚Äôre highly schizophrenic. And I think that‚Äôs one of the reasons why there is so much diversity in thinking. This also allows millennials to jump between the different people he or she can be. It isn‚Äôt uncommon to see a millennial have a completely different outlook within a span of 2-3 years. With access to so much information, with days dragging on and nights getting harder, it is a generation that treats time differently. I think one of the biggest myths is that they‚Äôre nationalistic, politically motivated and charged. Perhaps this is because of the halo of people like  or the disproportionate media coverage given to cases like Jessica Lal‚Äôs, where a large number of youth took to the streets or Anna Hazare‚Äôs movement against corruption. In India, young people have always taken to the streets. Be it pre-independence, in the 70s or even the 90s. So the idea of Indian Youth being politically motivated isn‚Äôt new. What is new however, is that this young India now has the world at its fingertips, wants to have a worldview and wants to have their opinion known. Case in point: the number of young Indians from the likes of AIB to an average Joe in Kanpur who put up long sermons about how Trump coming to power is the End of The World.  playing on sentiments of nationalism would do well if they enable Indian youth to engage in the lip service they pay their country. Or provide them with a new way to be seen or think how the nation is governed. The same applies to entrepreneurship. The Bansals have probably given this halo of millennials being entrepreneurially inclined. However, according to a recent EY survey, 44% prefer staying with one company through their career. Only 22% want to start up. The number who eventually do is smaller. What‚Äôs also interesting about millennials and Gen Z  is that ‚Äònew‚Äô or ‚Äònovel‚Äô or ‚Äònoteworthy‚Äô doesn‚Äôt remain that for too long. As soon as a first batch have shared something and achieved glory, it loses its appeal. Lest the others seem ‚ÄúMe Too‚Äù. That brings me to the next myth. Brands believe millennials want to connect in ‚Äúcommunities‚Äù. Sunsilk Gang of Girls, Jaago Re, WeLoveMakeUp are all examples that prove otherwise. Millennials, according to me, are quite fickle. They want to plug and play in and out of ecosystems as opposed to getting entrenched in them. Each millennial is his or her own advertisement and his or her own community. Everyone wants to post, sing, dance, and build followings around themselves. They don‚Äôt want to belong, or be tied down into something and get defined by it. It comes back to the point that a millennial could be a totally different person every two years. They‚Äôre about re-invention as opposed to definition. Brands that can aid re-invention and either be at the cutting edge of culture or be so utilitarian in terms of consistency and price that they become almost second nature, are likely to thrive. The final myth: digital is the ‚ÄòHoly Grail‚Äô. To ‚Äúown‚Äù millennials, marketers will need to understand how they link with each other, with brands, with influencers, with media platforms and devices. India‚Äôs millennials haven‚Äôt yet shifted their entertainment preferences online. Less than 2% of 18-34-years old changed the channel during commercials, compared with 5.5% of 35-54-years old and more than 8% of viewers 55 and older. Given their engagement with other devices, however, millennials had the lowest program engagement and lowest ad memorability scores. So, they‚Äôre not paying attention. Hence the thought maybe let‚Äôs catch them on digital. There one sees stats like Facebook ads drive 5% incremental reach for SEC AB as compared to TV - however the truth is the average amount a user spends on a video on Facebook is 1.3 seconds. In such a short span how much can be communicated? This is not to say that digital doesn‚Äôt work but it certainly isn‚Äôt a ‚Äòdeploy and win‚Äô medium where one size fits all. It‚Äôs an interesting, differentiated and diversified generation, one that doesn‚Äôt pay attention and would rather build its own brand or community, assimilating other brands and communities. One that‚Äôs happy moonlighting among various personality types, ecosystems and brands. And one that won‚Äôt accept being put into a homogenous bucket.

I'm writing this for my friend Ranveer Allahbadia...

Life is challenging and it can test you. Ranveer has learnt that recently. One controversy, and years of value someone brought and hard work someone put in, can wither away. I‚Äôve also been advised not to be associated with him by lots of people I respect. That's how hard some of this can be. But a friendship is a friendship. And the lens through which I‚Äôve seen him remains deeply valued and respected.

Ranveer has long been admired by the masses of India. People inherently love him for who he is. And along with the love he manages to generate, I admire his discipline, consistency, and how deeply he cares about what he puts out into the world.

I want to share about three pieces of content I loved that helped me appreciate him better and learn from his work.

First is his latest documentary on hair. A powerful mix of vulnerability and research. One of the best pieces I‚Äôve seen on the subject. It‚Äôs classic Ranveer in a new avatar that people have loved, and people have always loved him for adding value to their lives. He does it in a great way here.

Second is his ‚ÄòTaakat‚Äô episode with Suresh Raina. It reinvented the podcast format. Not the same static setup. It felt like you were in the room with them. It shows how well he understands film and camera.

Third is his piece on the platinum button. The way it was shot and delivered was exceptional. The kind of content that reminds you why you started.

People have said rude things. Doubted him. Scrutinized his every word.
Through all the noise, he‚Äôs kept creating. Kept showing up.

He‚Äôs doing some of the best work I‚Äôve seen. I respect him for that. And I love him like a brother.

Do Not Make This Leadership Mistake! Early in my career, I had a rough approach with my team. Reflecting on my past behaviour, I realized I was mimicking a role model I admired. This person was successful and had a similar approach of being abusive with their team. Sometimes the abusive nature was borderline funny. Almost Ari Gold esque. Because I looked up to this role model, I didn‚Äôt fully consider the impact of my behaviour. I just replicated it, assuming it was the recipe for success. Someone so good is doing it ‚Äì how wrong can I go? This experience taught me an important lesson about leadership: we must be very mindful of how we carry ourselves in public. Whether we realize it or not, as leaders, we are magnets for behavior modeling. Our actions and words are easily replicated by those who look up to us.
